500ml bottle. Pours black in colour with a stable brown foam head and aroma of roast malts, bitter chocolate, dark fruits, treacle, honey. Rich complex sweetish taste fruity dark peaty malt, chocolate, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, coffee, nutty, warming bitter and boozy. Silky smooth mouthfeel, full bodied, soft carbonation, powdered chocolate finish with some peaty & alcohol notes. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2016 Black, with brown head that does not last long. Aroma is dark chocolate, heavy roasted, raisin, some alcohol (does not disturb), some peat (especially on the finish), a little bit of honey when warmed. Not sweet, but not very bitter as well. Overall, tasted like an Imperial Stout. Maybe could be a bit more smooth. Good one.

Pours a dark brown coffeelike body with a really thin head. A rich aroma and a taste full of coffee tones.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Basically sweet and roasty tar. Flavourful as few beers, but this is potent stuff. I have had beers with much higher ABV, but something in this balance made it very hard to get down, very sweet underneath the roastiness. Still worth a try.

Intense chocolate and toffee aroma with some roasted notes 
Black with thick beige head 
Taste start chocolaty sweet but quickly turns to intense bitterness full of roastiness and coffe. Really great long lasting bitterness 
Full body with average carbonation and pretty texture 
Very rich and intense beer. Really nice for a long sitting, could do in smaller volumes

Bottle. Pours almost black, nice head. Aroma is dominated by the peated malt, but there are also notes of roasted malts, chocolate and honey. In taste there are flavours of peated and roasted malts, dark fruits and honey. Beer is full bodied, low carbonation, low bitterness. Very good, well balanced beer.

500ml brown bottle, poured into a snifter glass. Appearance is opaque nearly black dark mahogany, with a medium sized mocha colored head, with good retention. Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate and rye sourdough bread. Flavours of chocolate, rye sourdough bread, honey, roasted malts and muscovado. Taste is light-medium sweet and medium bitter. Palate is full bodied, creamy texture and average carbonation. Overall a great well balanced and flavorful Imperial Stout like beer.

Bottle(@KrisWines, British Empire):Literally black, mid-sized stable tanned head, flavours of a dry english strong ale (dry fruits, ashes, caramel and port-wine) with a solid bitter honeyish touch and well detectable touch of barnyard ( or ((horse)) stables); solid bitter-sweet flavour, full bodied, velvet MF; roasted malt, ashes, caramel, nuts, portwine and barnyard in the finish. Very good stuff

Pours black with a massive mocha head that slowly settles, leaving sticky lacerations in the glass. Dipping in the nose and giving the glass a swirl gives off aromas of milk chocolate, honey, citrus, soil, vanilla, slight herbal notes, brown sugar, roasted malts. Taste is surprisingly fruity: fresh dark red fruits initially thar quickly gives way to milk chocolate, honey, lavendel, spices, brown sugar. Mouthfeel is very creamy and round with medium carbonation. Aftertaste is milk chocolate, honey, slight spices and vanilla. Very good and nicely balanced.
@ Ölprovning på Havregatan 7 mars 2014. Mycket smak, kaffe, kakao, lakrits, rostade toner, en viss syrlighet, trä, BA-toner, fyllig (nästan krämig), oljig i konsistensen. Maltig och besk avslutning.
Bottle from 16 Tons Taphouse, Eugene. Pours a nearly opaque reddish black, little bit of tan head. Aroma strong cough syrup, honey. Body lively, finishes bracing, licorice. Tasty.

Bottle @ Cardinal. Black body with a finger thick, stable beige head. Interesting and a bit unusually in aroma, dark malt, dark berries, chocolate and some alcoholic scent in the direction of honey/mead. Flavor is very pleasant, with dark malt, berries, nice balanced bitterness and the same strange honey kind of warming alcohol. Fine body and long aftertaste. An interesting and pleasant beer that becomes better and better further down the bottle.

Bottle. Black body, with a medium, creamy, tan head, that wont last very long. Complex aroma of honey, nuts, dark chocolate, coffee, alcohol. Tastes of dark chocolate, coffee, nuts, wood, smoke, bitter honey, dried fruits, rum. Mouthfeel is full, oily, with a medium carbonation and it finishes complex, alcoholic, bitter-roasty and dry, with honey, coffee, cocoa beans, earth, wood, smoke. What a complex beer! The honey notes are really interesting, as they arent sweet at all and add even more complexity. A heavy beer, that you can only enjoy slowly, but it reveals more and more dark aromas as it warms up.
Dark with nice generous soft head. Aroma chocolate & roasted notes. Taste bittersweet chocolate, roasted malt. Full body, low carb, finish bittersweet. Reminds me of Brooklyn chocolate stout.

Bottle, shared with Parksy and Grippitis. Silky and nearly black with a dense brown head. Sweet honey and hazelnut and Maple Cookies, just a kiss of smoke, birch syrup. Rich and complex and incredibly balanced. Superb.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle @home (catching up on my back-log and ive had the bottle for approx one year). Pours black with a tan head. Nice Co2 , not huge on the nose, understated, malty, a touch of coffee also a hint of sweetness. It come a live on the palate. Huge liquorice, big coffee, fruity (dark dried fruits) the alcohol is there but i would not say it was 10% badboy. Slight sherry kick also chocolate coming through with a nutty bitter finish. This is one hell of a beer. Just wonderful.

Absolutely gorgeous beer. Jet black like an Imperial Stout when poured into the tulip glass. Brown head, small, nice lacing. Aroma of coffee beans, chocolate, honey, anise, taste is the same. Velvet mouthfeel, finish is extraordinary. Amazing beer.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks ArizviSG. Black with tan head. Wine, ink and gouache paint aroma, inky, bitter, slightly dry and slightly roasty in the mouth, full body, sleek, light carbonation and a little roasty finish.
Pours bkack with beige head. Aroma is roasted, licorice, chocolate, bread and nuts. Flavour is medium to heavy bitter, light sweet, roasted and licorice.
Mørk farge brunkt skum. Smak av malt, sjokolade, honning. Lukter malt og sjokolade. Veldig god

Bottle, from Thornbridge Online, at the mass online Thornbridge/Oakham Tasting of 11/02/14.
Pitch black with a mahoosive dirty tan head - utter filth in fact, this subsided after a few mintutes to leave a covering and edgework, finally ending up as the shape of a scary hedgehog.
Nose is chocolate malt, spice, herbal tang, chocolate biscuits, dark fruits on the turn.
Taste comprises bitter chocolate, earthy hopped backbone, spice, herbal, light shades of that Hungarian Zwak affair a la light creosote, bitter dark fruit rinds.
Medium bodied carbonation is a little prickly but helps this 10% number drink more easily.
So I let this one warm up over an hour or so and it didnt improve the flavours massively.
Solid for style, drinkable for 10%, but not one Id rush back to time and again.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 500 mL bottle supplied by Leighton for our IP trade. Many thanks! To oversized brandy snifter, it pours a deep, dark purplish brown with which a quickly-diminishing tan khaki ringed head, 1 finger in length, rested atop. Aromas of prunes, toasted breadcrumbs, hazelnut butter, oak, blackstrap molasses, butternut squash purée, autumnal leaves, burnt leather, booze, sugarcane, red licorice, and sourdough. Tastes the same with the addition of peat smoke, spearmint, melted wax, and marsh rosemary by mid-palate. By swallow, its hinting at chestnuts, pine needles, semi-sweet chocolate, castagnaccio, stale coffee, raisins, and black lime. Citric acid also present. Bitey and versatile. Bloody fuckin good.

Bottle. Very nice dark brown body with tan lasting white head. Aroma is dried fruits, roasted malts and some honey. Taste is roasted malts caramel and fruits very balanced between sweet and bitter. Aftertaste is sweet honey and bitter. Very balanced and nice one.

500ml bottle from the brewery online shop. Deep, dark brown with a big tan head. Smoky and metallic aromas, bubblegum and coffee. Lots going on. Seems to smell a bit different every time... Lemon and chocolate coming through now. Great aromas. Taste has all this going on too, and a good balance between bitter and sweet - sometimes big beers this strength are too sweet on the finish, but this has dried out well, assuming the champagne yeast has something to do with that. Getting something nutty now, on the taste. Full-bodied,rich and creamy. Long finish. Very nice beer.

At a tasting, many thanks DSG, zvikar and Ariel, small beige head, totaly black colour, aroma of wax, old shoes, glue, hints of charred wood and roastiness, flavour of dark chocolate with hints of smoke, wax, charred wood and dirt, with some fruitiness coming and going, long and intense dark chocolate aftertaste. Intriguing beer which is quite difficult to drink.
A: Deep black with some red tint. S: Caramel, whisky. T: Strong liquorice, alcohol really feels. Some acid, plum, lots of fruit. M: Oily, Tangy feeling in mouth. O: Complex.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Beer Market Jaffa. Black-colored with a light brown head. Aroma of dark malts, some roastiness, some chocolate, dark fruits and floral honey notes. Sweet flavor with a light acidic note, chocolate, a bit of honey, some dark fruits touches, mild roastiness and a finish with light hoppiness. Rather full-bodied, quite silky and rounded. Very good and complex.
On tap at bitter creek. Pours out black topped with a small tan head. Nose is roast malts smoke and some hops. Taste is smoke malts black licorice and some molasses.

On tap at bittercreek, pitch black pour with little head. Nutty, bitter chocolate, a little ash. This guys assaults your tongue at first taste, then proceeds to mellow in roasted chocolate heaven. Awesome beer
On tap at BitterCreek Ale house black with a trace of a light tan head and a faiint dry roasted aroma. Big roasted flavor with lots of ash and soot. Almost ash-tray smokey nutty and dusty.

Totally black beer with deep cinnamon coloured head on top. Aroma offers roasted malts, honey, nuts, syrup. Definitely a sweet one here. Pleasantly sweet beer. Roasted malts with honeyed nuts and bitter drying roasted feel in the end. Full body and medium carbonation. Pretty excellent honeyed ale.

50cl bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a nice brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, sweet, chocolate, honey, quite complex. Flavor is sweet and bitter, also chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, alchool but not as much as you would expect from a 10% Traditional Ale. Full bodied and sticky, soft carbonation. Great
Bottle from 2012. Dark brown with a small brown head. malty and nutty tones. malt, caramel, fruit, coffee and chocolate. Full body with a long, bitter sweet finish.

Bottle @ Maxs, courtesy of Valgreen, Thanks. Pours black with a fading creamy brown head. Aroma is malts, wood, little peat, light earthy, dark chocolate. Flavor is malt, nuts, peat, earthy, dark chocolate, burnt caramel bitter grapefruitlike hops. Full body, oily mouthfeel, soft carbonation, bitter finish with some warming alcohol. 121213

Bottle BB Feb 2017.  Thick black pour, big brown head doesnt endure long. Decent lacing. Smell - refresher sweets, lots of nag champa incense, orange peel, touch of alcohol. Body is medium to full, slightly foamy and medium carbonation. Taste - sweet, spice, apple, slight spearmint, more incense, toffee, touch of grapefruit, rounded peated finish, slightly sharp. This is a good beer. Sorachi Ace is probably my least favourite hops, and the fact that I enjoyed this despite their obvious presence says a lot. I would love to try this with a different hop combination. I would call this an imperial stout personally.

Aroma: Strong espresso coffee, moderate peat, hazelnut, dark honey, and basically all the other stuff the label says. Very complex and full of fantastic anticipation. Appearance: Poured a oily, almost chunky black with a bubbly mocha head that settled into a bubbly ring. Flavor: Matches the nose; Hazelnut and honey up front with a dusting of coffee; strongly roasty and peaty towards the finish. Palate: Medium body, oily texture, flat carbonation, long finish. Overall: Certainly one of the finest beers from Great Britain, and a real privilege to find over here. Bottle from Louisville Beer Store.

Bottle. Black beer with a brown head. Rch malt and toffee aroma with light honey. Toffee and chocolate flavor with light coffee and light citrus. Medium-plus bodied. Toffee and chocolate linger with light fruitiness and light coffee.
Dark brown color, small steady brown color. Licorrice, honey, cough syrup, complex! Full-bodied. Dark malts. Lots of honey. Roasted finish. Complex and interesting beer.
UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 Very thick and dark, lovely tan head. Aroma is dark berries, light peat, malt. Taste is syrupy, very sweet, light smokiness and honey at end. Overall, lots going on - nice.

Honig im nachklang/abgang gut spürbar. Feinherb, leicht schokoladig und likörig.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled. Pours opaque black with a creamy, tan and lacing head Aroma of honey, nuts, roasted malts and chocolate. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry, with some malt bitterness and alcohol notes. Medium bodied, oily to creamy text. and soft carb. An excellent ale indeed.

Draft poured a chestnut brown with a light foamy head.
Mild flavor of roasted nuts, cocoa, peat. Honey like sweetness, well balanced
Draft. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Light smoky-ish malts, dark chocolate, some nutty , and some faint flowery hops in the finish. Rich, and a little fruity. Good stuff.

Draft in the Avenue Pub in Nawlins!!! ... Deep black brown ... Solid gamer foam ... Dark fruit . Burnt scotch vapors and mild madness inducing brandy cooking chocolate ... Good and very intoxicating .. . , Fozzy bear was a rapist..

Black color with small beige head. Aroma of cream, chocolate, nuts, cappuccino, peat, liquorice. Taste is medium bitter, light sweet a bit savory. Perfect balance. Full body, velvety texture, flat carbonation. One of the best beers I have had, if not the best. Closest to perfection.

Pours a dark brown with a moka head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is full of peat, spices, herbs and really different overall. Taste is really sweet, almost cloying. Lots of honey and roasted malt and some chocolate is what I could taste. Full bodied and a little heavy. Mouthfeel is smooth, though. Overall a fun one, makes me wonder how the original ("real") recipe tasted (pretty sure it wasnt as nice as this bottle!).

pours clear dark brown with a nice beige head, good retention and lacing. mint, burnt caramel, soy sauce, roastiness, bitter chocolate, cloying molasses and dark sugars, smoke, hickory. moderate to low carbonation, medium to full body - heavy stuff, slightly earthy and grassy-minty finish. complex but oh-so-not-overwhelmed by this sweet and umami-ed brew.

Bottle 500ml.
Pours black with low creamy light brown head. Aroma is of stable, peat, alcohol, chocolate, roasted malt, musty. Taste is of peat, chocolate, roasted malt, fruits, alcohol. Palate: Full bodied. Overall: Very complex, awesome peatiness. Serious stuff.

Bottle (500 ml). From AlexFields, thanks! Dark reddish brown with a small/medium fully lasting brown head and some lacing. Aroma of peated malt, mint, chocolate, honey and nuts. Taste is slightly sweet and about the same as aroma, maybe a tad more nutty. Medium body. Low to moderate carbonation. Somewhat silky mouthfeel. Pretty unique beer. Nice peated touch. Good balance and drinkability for a 10% abv beer. Complex and well balanced. Loved it.

Appearance: Sinful dark black color with a frothy big beige head. Nice lacing.Aroma: Chocolate, vanilla and fruity.Palate: Thick oily body. Slightly sweet and an ok bitterness. Soft carbonation.Taste: Coffee, chocolate and nice smooth balanced fruity. Dangerously well masked alcohol.Overall impression: Tasty and powerful ale. One more please. The only problem now: Where can I get another bottle...Personal stats: Bottle from Vinmonopolet Vika in Oslo, Norway.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2015 Denso color nero con un cappello mediamente spesso di schiuma marroncino chiaro. Al naso offre frutta fresca, miele, cacao, farina di castagne, frutta secca e più velati sentori di caffè e malti tostati; al palato è un fantastico equilibrio di sapori tra i quali emergono pere, miele di rododendro e castagno, cereali e cacao amaro. Al palato è perfetta: elegante, fine, cremosa, vellutata, gentilmente effervescente e di corpo abbondante; labv non si sente e ogni sorso invita al successivo. Una birra "aristocratica", favolosa.
Medicinal long prune snappy with some bloodiness. Meaty.fantastic complexity & depth. So so long. Wow.

500ml bottle. Pitch black colour with late awakening, average to huge, frothy to creamy, half-way lasting, moderately lacing, brown head. Dark malty aroma has fruity notes of blue/dark berries, hints of milk chocolate, a touch of nougat, hoppy overtones. Taste is moderately sweet, intense dark malty, notes of treacle, chocolate, dark berries, liquorice, a touch of roast, a salty touch, cautious hints of peat, minimally bitter, herbal hoppy overtones, cautious hints of alcohol; slightly oily texture, sticky palate. Very rich and complex taste.

Bottle @ Exmouth Arms, London. Pitch black, small tan head, good lacing. Aroma, deep roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, a very rich sweetness, . Taste, roasted malts, sweet burnt sugar, chocolate, coffee, licorice, . Nice mouth feel. Slightly oily. Roasted honey aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2013 Bottle, 12C. Black with a tan head that fades to a coat, leaving spots of lacing. Aroma of hazelnuts, the forest floor, chocolate, cherries, twangy medicinal honey, the lodge. Silky mouthfeel, low carbonation. Sweet spiced chocolate, hazelnuts, autumnal detritus, coffee, cherries, complex toasty caramelised/ singed flavours. Cocoa and spices (anise, galangal, licorice, coriander root) linger, honey is more obvious. Bitterness creeps up. Alcohol is well-integrated, but it drinks like a strong brew. Brings to mind a large room - used only occasionally but well-maintained and stacked with seasoned wood - in the last sunny days before the fire must be lit. Spectacularly good. [4.6]Went on a bit then, but yes, a really stunning beer. Dark, burnt, spicy gruit things, modern hops that should jar but dont at all. Mysterious herbal notes that pop in and out of prominence. Big and complex, but nothings that shouty and yet everythings well defined.

Bottle from Mane Liquor at the Thornbridge tasting. Pours oily black with a short, khaki head. Aroma of cocoa, caramel, and a sweet smokiness. Taste opens up a thick chocolate body with a nice roasty background, travels through the mouth with a touch of caramel and coffee, leaving a lingering aftertaste of cocoa and almost a caramel peat. A really pleasant, sweet smokiness. Proved to be different to the standard coffee/chocolate stout, good to see.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2013 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours very dark with a small, sticky tan head. Nose shows smoke instantly. As it opens up, a fair bit of sweetness comes out but its a balanced sweetness. Almost like sweet hickory smoke with some heavy caramel and powdery chocolate in there too. Very complex stuff - firewood, dark chocolate, powdered chocolate, sweet & sticky honey, peat, toffee. Finishes with a very caramelised/honey forward peatiness right on the back end with a touch of coconut. Works extremely well and I can see why this is so highly regarded. Very solid stuff

Bottle at mane liquor thornbridge tasting night. Pours a dark brown/black with a frothy tanned head. Nose is quite interesting. Nutmeg and bitter chocolate with dark roasty malts. Taste is much more of the same. Heaps of dark chocolate malts coming through even a touch of coconut towards the end of the palate. Fucking interesting beer Im finding it hard to describe. Would definitely recommend trying for pure complexity. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From 500 ml bottle. Poured in a Rader tulip glass.
Pours black with brown head.
Aroma of chestnuts, dark chocolate, milk chocolate, honey.
Significant carbonation and big mouthfeel.
Flavors of bitter chocolate, honey grahams, milk balls, alcohol, liquid smoke, burnt roasted malts, molasses, cream of tartar, rosemary. Overall a big and bold brew with lots of dark roasty notes, significant alcohol, chocolates.
Dark brown almost black pour, creamy tan head. Nose is prunes, figs, booze. Taste is booze, prunes, chocolate syrup, very sweet. Lingering sticky sweetness. Sticky smooth mouthfeel.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle. Bottled Winter 2010. Black with a tan head. The aroma is roasted malt, perfume, flowers, hazelnuts and honey. The flavor is equally complex. I get a lot of perfume and cocoa notes, but they are complimented by the hazelnuts, sweet honey, black licorice and alcohol. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
UPDATED: JUL 10, 2013 Bottle. Pours dark brown. Nose and taste of honey, floral, dark fruit in chocolate, cappuccino, chestnut and chocolate covered orange peel. Medium body.

A black beer with a beautiful, creamy, medium and brown head. The nose is enjoyable and balanced, roastiness, liquirice, strong salt liquirice, also some dark fruits and even port wine, alcohol can be sensed but not smelled. Taste is intensive, lots of salt liquirice, roastiness, dark fruits, warming alcohol, hint of coffee. Lots of sweetness, but it is balanced with bitterness and also other very intensive flavours. Strong bitterness dries the end and the aftertaste is roasted, slightly herbal and very long. Full bodied, low carbonation, very smooth to drink, but slightly sticky in the lips. The great beer, very intensive and complex.

Aroma is delightful and roasty. Great malts, toffee, chestnuts, honey, and chocolate. Pours black with a small short lived brown head. Taste is wonderful with toffee, chocolate, ginger snaps, licorice, roast malt and amazing caramel. The beer feels full and rich without showing its booze. Wonderful treat.

Dark brown, almost black with edges of ruby. Frothy mocha coloured head, medium lasting. Big aromas - port, oak, cherries, cassis, honey, hazelnut, cereal, coffee and milk chocolate. Really lovely. Intense flavours and rich, lush mouthfeel, getting resiny dark chocolate, nuts, coffee. Carbonation is soft, buts its there. Huge body on this, so rich. Finish is intensely complex, chocolate and coffee, liquorice, some piney bitterness and a nice dose of warming alcohol. This is truly lovely.

Sample at Freakin Frog in Las Vegas. The beer is a brownish-black color with a medium tan head that recedes gradually. Strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of toffee, malt and fruit. Full-bodied with flavors of earthy malt, dark fruit, chocolate and a bit of alcohol. The finish is sweet with a chocolate malt aftertaste. Good beer all around.
Pours a black color with a slight burnt coffee aroma. Taste is dry and butter. Slight fruityness at the very beginning that disappears quickly. Pretty good beer!

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2014 This is not a beer is a medicine, masterful example of what it means to love the land and the fruits that it gives. Aroma and taste of honey, dried fruit, Smoked, dark chocolate, the aroma of Burbon, a fairy tale.
Svart farve med beige gyllent skum som forsvinner. Lukt av malt og sjokolade. Smak av malt, sjokolade, kaffe og søt honning. Vinmonopolet.

Bottle. bbd 27/02/17, so young. Pitch black with a coffee colored foamy head. Wow - the aroma is great. Its medicinal, coffee, pepto bismoly and a touch of chocolate but really complex with a touch of sweetness and malt and something floral about it. Holy fuck, its something else - so syrupy, sticky, chewy and rich in the mouth. Boozy, but its still smooth for something so strong. the medicinal stuff is big, which isnt my favorite but its sweet and malty and chocolatey and has some coffee bitterness... oh, its lovely.

Bottle. Black with light tan head. Slight smokey, or rather tar-y, dark malts - some dry chocolate, a bit of roasty. Has dark toffee, grainy maltiness, with a bit of herbal hoppyness. Very intensive flavours, very nice. Body is thick,  slightly oily. But leaves a dry finish. Brown dark maltiness. Somewhat like an RIS, but not salty licoricy, more brown malty, chocolatele. Really nice, and drinkable.
Draft. Pours a dense blackish brown with a thick and creamy tan head. SMell and flavor are smokiness, roasted malt, chocolate, nuttiness, sooooo rich and delicious.

Bottled, 500ml (9.0%abv), aged 4yrs. from Bellingers Garage, Grove, Oxon. Black with tan head. Thick, smooth, velvety beer with a big liquorice, tarry nose on opening. The pour is slow, like easing the beer out of the bottle. There is cocoa powder initially on the palate with a charred coffee ovelay, deeply roasted malts. There is a hoppiness, but the ageing has smoothed this into the beer, but I get a lighter fruity note. Undoubtedly a superb beer.
Good creamy coffee aroma, mild grassy hop notes. Black colour. small stable brown head. Good sweet roasted flavour. Good hop flavour, sweet and spicy, very grassy finish

Bottle from Stirchley Wines; dark black pour with luxurious big tan head, dark fruit and alcohol aroma, rich dark dried fruit taste, light smokiness very complex and bold some earthy wet leaves like action, vanilla, leather. Has a decent level of bitterness. Mouthfeel is can only be described as luxurious. Wonderful beer.
Quite nice but not so pale. NIce aroma and somewhat different than those who will be on cask.

A - Dark brown-black with a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. Fades fairly slowly.

S - Sweet dark caramel and toffee malts, dark fruits, honey, smoke, nuttiness, vanilla, oak, bit of booze.

T - Sweet dark caramel and toffee malts, dark fruits, honey, vanilla, oak, smoke, nuttiness, black licorice, and a bit of booze.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a sweet, warming finish.

D - Nice complex and balanced English Strong Ale.
Firkin at My Place Pizza. Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Smells of roasted malt, some honey undertones, nutty, spicy. Tastes sweet with a nice blend of roasted malt and honey. Enjoyable.

500ml Bottle - Black with a tan head. Honey, bubblegum, pomerans, tar, plain chocolate and liquorice in the aroma. Sweet, malty, rich and fruity taste with coffee, honey, orange peel, liquorice, smoked malt and Bournville chocolate. Incredibly complex yet so smooth and easy to drink. Delicious.

wow this beer is AWESOME Black with a lasting tan head. Aroma of fruit and chocolate ith a little licorice. Sweet chocolate flavour, with grassy hops and a hint of smoke. Incredibly rich and thick mouthfeel. Outstanding complex roasted flavour and long finish

Delicious - simply delicious! As in the nose, hazelnuts and honey are well noted, along side chocolate, a little roasted malt, molasses, dark fruit (black cherries and raisins) and a distinct earthy quality. Warming brings more of the dark fruits, molasses and a touch of peat, but the 10% stays totally hidden.

Beautiful dark brown body with a small dark brown head. Strong sweet aroma with licorice, caramel, honey, coffee and peat. Excellent, smooth and complex bittersweet flavour with chocolate, licorice, coffee, nuts, bread, some dark fruits and honey. Great.

From a 500ml bottle. Jet black pour with a small foamy head and a quite lively carbonation. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, honey, hazelnut. I get a noticeable lavender note which makes this brew a bit unusual and makes it stand apart from other dark, strong ales, a bit like those parma violet sweets. Really nice, well balanced. sweet to start with the hops taking over with  a rounded slightly bitter finish. Top brewing. Excellent.

Bottle 50 cl, BBE 25.11.2016. Pours dark brown in color with a beige, quite   fast disappearing head. Notes old rubber, some peat and something sweet, Im guessing that would be the contribute of the Chestnut Honey in this case. Light burnt wood as well in aroma, later on also some smokyness appears. Sweet honey-like notes in taste, some coffee being present as well, light burnt wood, some peaty notes. Wood and espresso with some light smokyness, delicious. Rich mouthfeel on the whole. Incredibly smooth for that matter too. Notes of bitter chocolate and more coffee notes appears as well. Some faint notes of salty seawater is there too. Still gotta praise the smoothness in this brew, its just incredible and while leaving the nice aftertaste with some coffee and light burnt wood, I just love it.
Bottle. Dark coffee with a caramel head, good lacing. Aroma is nut and roast malt. Flavour is dark fruit, peak, chocolate with a sweet syrupy finish. Texture is creamy velvet.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis.
Clear black pour.  Thin tan head.  Floral aroma.  The flavour is very complex.  An awesome beer

Bottle shared.  Pours dark brown with a ring tan head.  Aroma comes across very floral, totally unexpected.  Chocolate comes out with wood, honey, some coffee, burnt malts, licorice, prunes and vanilla.  Flavour is over moderate sweet and heavy bitter going long into the finish.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.  Theres so much going on with this beer - almost too much, but incredible.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Flavour is peat, licorice, chocolate, coffee, honey, nuts. Full body. Very nice beer.

Bottle from Johns Marketplace. This was one of those brews that I wanted for so long that seeing it on the shelf was a shock. Pours a deep black color with a medium brown head- totally different than expected. A rich nose of honey and roast, massive malt presence. The flavor is huge slightly smoky malts, dark fruit, honey, big earthy charcoal, bacon, just massive malt additions, something akin to seaweed. Reminds me a bit of a darker and less sweet Fourth Dementia from Kuhnenn. Excellent, unique and courageous.  There were no Anglo-Saxons in Britain at the time of the Roman conquest, instead the population were almost totally Celtic. Perhaps the word would have been béoir, something we use today still.

Bottle. Pours deep opaque black with a medium dark brown creamy head that slowly dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, molasses, sorghum. Flavor is the same, plus anise. Medium sweet, light bitter. Very full bodied and creamy in the mouth. Touch of woody astringence. Warming finish. Nice beer.

Pours opaque red/black with tan head.  Smells of wood, nuts, and smoke.  Peppery, smokey, and creamy.  Smoke, dark chocolate, espresso, chestnuts, alcohol, heavy cream, butter, charcoal, and a hint of lemon peel.  Finishes sticky and bitter, with a hint of creamy sweetness.  Lingers.

500. Thanks C! Pours black with a dense and creamy dark tan head. Big salty dark roasty nose--black olives and roast meat, like adam, very nice. Creamy dense body. Dark roast, heavy caramel, roast meat, and black olive mid palate. Long sticky roasty finish. Wonderful.

Bottle; Pour is murky brown with a fine bubbled khaki head in this glass. Retention is average, resulting in a ring and a haze, with light and spotty lacing present. This one is over a year old I suppose, and initially I thought it was turning for the worse. It did improve but I wonder if you should take the message about cellaring to heart here. The nose is hazelnut, roast, pine needles, sweet bread and honey, with a hint of cocoa present here. The flavor profile is initial bitter, moderate sweetness, revealing the grass and light pine, and moving to the compex malt profile. Roasted coffee bean, honey, caramel, cocoa, hazelnut, and light peat is present; Its somewhat bitter, mild alcohol note, and a bit of astringent character. Interesting brew, but fresher couldnt hurt this one.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a small brown head leaving lacing. Aroma is sweet smokey a bit perfume acidy astringent rasted malty. Flavor is sweet roasted malty; very nicely bitter. Good longlived bitter roasted malty finish.
Cask at Churchkey. Very smooth and delicious. Slightly sweet like honey and chocolate. Slightly bitter like liquorice and mild hops. Way too easy to drink.
Bottled, thanks to jtclockwork, dark brown with tall tan foam, aroma is chocolate and malty whiskey, flavor has chcocolate, malty port, peanut butter, prunes, duck sauce, good thick finish

Black pour with a 1 finger of offwhite head that laces well.  Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, a little smoke and bitter chocolate. Quite fruity, some smoky ash, roast malt.  Really unique beer. I  enjoyed it.

Pours a beautiful dark brown with minimal brown head. Aroma is mainly of roasted nuts and hints of chocolate. Taste is delightfully complex; the initial taste is sweet, nutty and roasted and morphs into good hoppy heaviness. The standout aspect of the beer is its rich, creamy mouthfeel. The finish is long - devastating. Overall, a brilliant beer to nurse for a good hour over a book or good conversation.

Riche,dense,consistant mais subtile,complexe en arômes et en saveurs ;fruits noirs-prunes- café torréfié noir - noir , amertume persistante en bouche mais bien agréable ..ALcool bien présent aussi ; légèrement fumée ,tourbée; vraiment du bon travail !

Pours a dark opaque brown with two fingers light brown head. Nose is strong coffee, slightly sweet and a little barnyard funk. Flavor is complex. A reasonably light sweet attack, sweet prunes and peach on the mid palate, and bitter coffee and more dark fruit on the finish. Mouth feel is silky and full bodied. Really delightful. Sweetness throughout is pleasant but not cloying. A big treat.

Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. An inky black thick oily beer with a powerful liquorice and paint?! aroma. It has liquorice, blackcurrant and red fruity flavours with slight chocolate and smooth vanilla on the finish.

500ml bottle from Santa. Pours rich dark brown with beautiful tan head. Very nice looking beer. Aromas of chocolate, dark fruits, caramel, toffee, nuts, rich dark malts, and a little peat. Flavors of rich dark malts, toffee, chocolate, bit of smoke, fair amount of dark fruit, touch of coffee and nuttyness. Has nice bitterness. Body is a little thinner than it looks, but there is a lot going on with brew. Nice level of complexity. Nice surprise and delicious beer.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2013 Bottled 50cl. Pitch black with a small beige head. Incredibly inviting complex nose. Great (mainly roasted) malt profile. Good bitterness. Lovely honey notes. Hints of wild strawberries. Full bodied. A great beer with plenty of character.

500 ml bottle from Bieropholie, served almost cold in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Very deep mahogany (almost black) with a nice deep mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Very deep and dark, black cherries, fairly fruity, molasses and treacle, very dark rye bread crust, some booze, big stuff!
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, full, slightly aggressive effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Huge, a ton of rich, dark, thick maltiness, quite fruity, more of the black cherries, molasses and treacle, dark chocolate, tree fruits, alcohol sting, wow; sweet with pretty good bitterness and a very long, inky, mouth-coating finish.

Not a beer to be taken lightly!

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2013 Bottle (and later draft) at Farmers Cabinet. Pitch black pour with a thick brown head. Black gummy raisin syrup. Spectacular! Saddle leather. Raisin pie. Liquorice. Sweet car engine. Dark black juicy flavors. Some peat. Dark, full and tremendous! Bit more smokey flavor appears as it warms. More than worth a try but may prove challenging to some. The chestnut flavor is quite nice.
bottle. darker pour. notes of dried fruits, raisins, chocolate , light coffee and good dose of peat/smoke. Quite flavorful, very complex. warming. Nice beer.

500 ml bottle courtesy of rlgk. Pours hazy dark brown with a rather small creamy mocha head that doesnt leave much trace while dissipating. Smell is sweet with toasted malts, rubber, asphalt, vanilla fudge, rubber, cereal, liquorice fudge, pine, wood, prunes, raisins, alcohol, cereal and hints of low quality milk chocolate. Taste is sweet, bitter and tiny sour with caramel, sweet dark bread, pine, freshly cut grass, resinous wood, sweet liquorice candy, bitter chocolate, rubber, asphalt, orange peal, alcohol, pine, lemon zest, sweet liquorice candy, sassafras and hints of sweetened dark roast coffee. Mouthfeel is slightly round, tiny astringent, tiny boozy and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and slightly bitter with toasted malts, caramel, toffee, pine, orange peal, asphalt, rubber, sweet liquorice candy and hints of citrus. A big disappointment... A bad bottle perhaps?
Bottle. Dark amber/brown beer with a small but lasting beige head. Malty cork aroma, fruity, vinous, some citrus and raisins. Mslty roasted flavor, rubber, caramel, hay. Huge amounts of rubber.

500 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a beige head. Aroma of strong caramel, bubblegum and some grass. Flavour of roasted malts, very sweet caramel, bubblegum, toothpaste, white chocolate and grassy hops. Full bodied, oily mouthfeel and a long, malty, salty, sweet finish. Way too sweet and rootbeer-y.

50 cl bottle.
Pours dark brown color with a small beige head. Aroma is very root beer like, almost toothpastey, some malts and caramel too. Flavor of toffee, caramel, some mint, toothpaste and mild fruits. This might be a good beer but I cant get past the toothpaste aroma and flavor.
5324

50 cl bottle @ olio, BBE 27.02.2017
Aroma has root beer and hints of herbs. Flavour has roasted notes, root beer, herbal notes and hints of cocoa. Completely different than I expected, a root beer with 10% more ABV than usually.

500ml bottle

Pours pitch black with a foamy head. Smells like root beer, notes of toothpaste, dark ripe fruits, hints of roastiness and nuts. Taste is sweet, smooth, slightlly roasty with notes of root beer, hints of nuts, hops and lingering chocolate notes. Finish is sweetish and roasty with long lasting spicy notes. Quite unique, spicy and root beerish.

Versa nera, con una bella testa bruna. Tostata, con note di miele e cioccolato. in bocca è ricca , dolce, rotonda mai noiosa, ancora miele, cioccolato, bruciato. piena e appagante, il top di questo natale.

Pours nearly black with medium dark tan head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of rich cocoa, cream, exotic coffee, oatmeal, dark amber honey, and a nice tree nut mixture.  Flavor matches well and comes together so nicely.  Gets better as it warms to room temperature.  Mouthfeel is slightly creamy and the aftertaste makes me want to keep sipping on it so that it never goes away.  What a great brew.

50 cl bottle @ home. Pours black with a light tan head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, honey, liquorice, and a little booze. Flavour is honey, roasted malt, caramel, and a little warming alcohol.

Bottle from Bierkonig, Amsterdam. Pours pitch black with a huge frothy tanned head. Aroma is sweet malty, liquorice, wood and some flowery sweetness. Taste is a big surprise, full bodied, smooth, light roasted malts, ash,a distinct sweetness, like flowers and plums, suitable carbonation level,
lingering malty goodies, included light salty liquorice, a true gem of a beer.

Bouteille de 500 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Légère odeur de chocolat et de prunes. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun moyen col brun mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de chocolat avec une pointe dalcool et de fruité. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût chocolaté. (Rating #4490)
Black colour. Halelnat and dark malt aroma. Taste is more hazelnut, malt, chocolate. Very nice.

0.5l bottle. Looks so majestic even before popping the cap. Anyhow, the beer itself looks at least as majestic, if not even more. Deep oily dark brown with a small bubbly and islandy chocolate head that looks like bubbly stratos chocolate. It really does look like thick dark motor oil with a nice little head. On the nose its intensely sweet and delicious with soy sauce, woodwork, roasted barley, chocolate, smooth licorice, anise and a little bit of warming perfectly integrated booze. It smells amazing. Its thick, creamy and really viscous in texture and it has a soft prickling just perfect carbonation level. 2013.01.07 - Thornbridge Bracia - 16.9oz bottle in pint glass.   I'm a fan of braggots and things made with honey so I have high hopes.  

Pours dark with a caramel head, visually looking like a stout.  Head goes quickly, little evident cabonation.  Aroma as it poured almost gave a bit of a minty fragrance.  As it warms up it moves more towards a generalized sweetness, no hops, no yeast; maybe a bit of coffee.  

First drink, roast like a stout is obvious but disappears very quickly and is replaced by sweetness.  Label mentions liquorice, might not have noticed if it didn't say so but I can definitely pick it out now.   This reminds me a bit of some of the things in the "Black Saison" category like New Holland Four Witches.  Mouthfeel is a bit creamy, little carbonation.   

Overall, good.  A bit expensive for any repeat purchase, but this is the only bottle I've ever seen so it may not be an option anyway.  A bit more roast/peat sort of favors than expected but definitely good and interesting.  Not as good as braggots I enjoy but definitely tasty.

50 cl bottle from Vinmonopolet Vika. Pours oilyblack with a big brown head. Aroma of honey, nuts and dark fruits. Complex beer with a very well hidden alcohol. More nuts and honey with some coffee and chocolate in the flavour. Very nice mouthfeel.

Appearance:
Dark blacks under a dark espresso crema head. A thick head of crema hued foam fades into a thick collar which also swirls thick. A very alluring image of a beer.

Nose:
Berries and honey. Honey glazed and flambéed over a brilliant red-hot flame, the honey crackling and sizzling as they cooked along with the strawberries and raspberries. Sweet dark breads packed with juicy plump raisins  pumpernickel if you please. Black licorice root. Mulberries. Root beer candies.

Palate:
Interesting from start to finish. Dark fruits abound  plums, raisins, and prunes  covered in honey and berry glaze. Fresh  no artificial preservatives and additives need apply. Smokey and rooty in the back and along the edges  tendrils. Black licorice also in the back swallow. Burnt caramel. A parching finish of black cacao powder, ash, and charcoal. Delicate berries covered in chocolate greet me at the beginning of each taste. More dry dark chocolates in the middle.

Final Thoughts:
Delicious! Interestingly delicious! I had heard good things about Englands Thornbridge brewery and it would seem they were true. This is my second beer from Thornbridge and hopefully it wont be my last. Quintessentially classically English. Cheerio!

Bottle (graduation present) from Dan - merci beaucoup! Pours a viscous looking black, small mocha head. Black and wearing a gentle beige head. Very complex and interestingly integrated nose with lots of stuff going on at once. An evident honeyed richness reminiscent of Polish mjods is first noticeable, but quickly uplifted by a roastiness that is never extreme and borders toastiness. Peated malt pairs with molasses and licorice to bring dark and leathery flavours forth. Plenty of raisins, plums and dates join the smoke in its dance, adding subtly vinous notes that are complex aplenty. It grows even more aromatic as it warms and in mouth, possesses enough tightness to evenlop and carry coherently all those flavors. UPDATED: NOV 28, 2013 My Bottom Line:
Pine and eucalyptus aromatics pervade this super rich strong ale, adding to a seamless mélange of molasses, peat smoke, figs, raisins, roasted malts and honey. Complex AND unique. Wow.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-Sizeable foam recedes to a slim veil atop the darkness.
-The aroma on this one is like no other strong ale Ive ever had.
-Hop resins are quite loquacious in the second half.
-The mouthfeel is dense and sticky, but not as viscous as some underattenuated Cigar City brews (for example).
-That bitter chestnut honey must be something else!
-If you served an Imperial Stout in a eucalyptus-filled sauna, it might taste like this. Then again, maybe not...
-A touch of alcohol warms each sip.

Bottle. Spicy aroma with notes of salmiak, chewing gum and smoke. Thick and smooth. Complex dark taste with heavy notes of chocolate. Also notes of smoke and salty licorice. Almost got too heavy after a while.

Doften är lite obestemmelig. Men smaken är riktig god. Tjock vätska. Tydelig choklad kaffe lakrits och tjära. Hyfsat lång eftersmak. God och kladdig.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Väldigt mörkt brun med beige skum. Doften domineras av frukttuggummi och tvål. Detta finns även i smaken men inte lika dominerande. Där hittar man även trä och en avslutande lätt bitterhet. Inte alls min typ av öl.

Masterful brew - classic Thornbridge: at once both defining and redefining a style. Rich and heady with the honey packing a punch. Not an imperial stout but a clear traditional ale. Not much else to say but this is one of the best english regular beers - file in the same category as VIntage Ale etc.

A bloody excellent UK beer! Pours black with a thick, medium tan head. Aroma is earth, hay, honey, cereal, some dark red fruit. Taste is where it really shines. Opens a bit flat but then picks up. Chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, prunes. Only a touch of bitterness, but more from the bitter honey (?) than from the hops. It's very, very balanced in its character. Finish is super long, with a hint of coffee lingering forever. Incredibly full and rich, yet not overly imposing. Despite its dark character it is very refreshing.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Very dark brown with a pale brown head. Aroma: lots of perfume, spice and soap, also chocolate and alcohol. Flavor: perfumy, sweet, smoke/barnyard, honey, chocolate, alcohol. Bitter and more dry towards the finish. The strong notes of perfume and soap ruined this for me. Disappointing!

Pours very dark, almost black, with brown head. Earty aroma with malts, nuttyness, wood and honey. Flavour is roasty and slightly smokey with nice earthy notes and well placed sweetness. Nice notes of chestnuts, chocolatey bitterness, honey sweetness and some salty licorice. Very long lasting aftertaste, a real sipper.

Pours dark and black with a thick resinous brown head.  Nose is roasted chestnuts and almonds, a little smokey, tree bark and cinnamon. Flavor is sweet with a small bitter and smoke flavor but the sweet dominates through to a bitter finish. Mouthfeel is pure silk. Smooth as hell. Long aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml Bottle (at 9%ABV per the Bottle):  Aroma of malt, chestnut, honey, slight dark ripe fruit, sugars, wood, dust, ash, and some scents I just cannot identify.  Poured pitch black in color with a large, loose, dark brown head that became creamy and dense and it diminished.  The head lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Flavor is strange and complex.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, chestnuts, wood, hazelnut, slight peat, nuts, hard roasting, and a hint of soy.  Medium body.  Oily, then dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Malt, roasting, chestnut, slight honey, slight peat, nut finish is medium sweet and dry.
Bottle. malty salty aroma with a hint of roastl. Malty sweet flavor with mango, citrus and salty notes. Tart. A bit like a roasted gose.

Style et résumé: Bière peu orthodoxe brassée avec du miel de noisette, Bracia étant un breuvage celte du moyen-âge.  
Comment: Bouteille de 500ml par IPB. 
Description: Pour une fois, la description dune bière sur une étiquette est véridique. Aucune menterie ici. Cette bière est vraiment riche, crémeuse, longue. Il y a de chocolat, du café, une touche fumé, du tabac, du miel en bouche comme au nez. Lalcool transporte les saveurs dune richesse inégalée. 
Note: 8+/10

50 cl bottle. Pours pitch black with a light brown head. Nose: burnt rubber, honey, chocolate, tiger balsam (really!)... Incredibly full obdy and rocketing sweetness. Taste is roasted, mocca, nutty. Finish is hoppy. Sweet bomb but nicely in balance. Love this beer!

Black as night, beige head. Lovely malty aroma, caramel, wood honey, coffee, chocolate and wild fruits. Soft malty flavour, honey, slight bitterness. Fresh bitter finish, honey tones, quite fruity with lingering malts. Nice!
(Taster glass from bottle @ ACBF 2012)

16/12/2011 Bir&Fud Bottega (500ml bottle). Magnifico color mogano, con meravigliosi riflessi rubini, schiuma finissima color cappuccino, abbondante e persistente. Naso notevole, anche se leggermente sporco, molto complesso, si percepiscono malti tostati, note legnose, di nocciola, cioccolato e luppolo. In bocca è sensazionale, lattacco è dolce, cioccolatoso con note di liquirizia, quindi vira sullamarognolo con un finale affumicato di una gentilezza e uneleganza unica. Equilibrio mirabile, persistenza lunghissima. Corpo medio, consistenza vellutata, carbonazione soft. Eccellente.

(50 cl.  BB 25/11/16)  Un liquide à la robe profondément brune.  Une magnifique tête.  Les traces de la viscosité de lalcool sur la paroi.  Un nez de malts rôtis et de praline belge (les manons!!) avec des céréales qui perdent une légère fumée de tabac.  Des noisettes grillées.  De la crème et du miel.  Un merveilleux nez.  Des saveurs de café aromatisé et des malts rôtis.  Du chocolat fourré à la noisette.  Du tabac à pipe.  Des houblons qui sexpriment.  Des oranges et des relents verts.  Un alcool qui perd quelques notes poivrées.  Des notes de pin.  Fantastique!  Une bouche solide.  Un pétillement modéré à faible.  Une texture soyeuse.  Une finale généreuse.  Des notes amères de torréfaction.  Des malts et des houblons.  Des notes citronnées touchées par la fumée.  Du miel et des noisettes sur les papilles.  Tout à fait brillant.

Bottle @ 5th ACBF 2012. A black colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of fruits with aseveral malts with notes of chocolate. The taste of a little smoked malt, fruity, parfumed. The aftertaste is bitter, smokie with notes of sweet.
Bottle courtesy of Dominick, thank you sir!  Hazy amber color, small tan head.  Aroma of fruity pine resin, taste is similar.  Good character and complexity.

Bottle sample @ ACBF 2012, Moen.
Brune foncée, col beige, filament doré huileux sur le verre.
Arôme est agréable et unique dans son bouquet de noix, de sirop dérable et de miel qui sont tous à noter sans que un prenne le dessus. 
En bouche, mélange subtile de noix donnant ce profile poudreux avec un aspect sucré dérable et ce côté organique de miel. Le tout est compléter par un beau profile malté sr une pointe de chocolat, de tourbe très subtile et où se retrouvent ces trois ingrédients. Le tout est compléter par un houblon subtile et efficace notamment le sorachi qui donne ce tonus fruité de citron frais.

Bottle.  Pours with the look of an imperial stout, cascading beautifully from dark tan foam into a oil-black beer.  Absent the description on the bottled, Id have found the sweet, floral aroma a bit surprising.  This drinks with a rich, rounded character of dark fruit -- plum and raisin -- accented with a unique twist that reminds me of pollen-rich spring, flowering and sweet.  Its an interesting mash up. (#4513, 3/2/2012)

Dark, dark colored pour. Looks black. Maybe the light isnt strong enough to penetrate it! Big tan head. Head is super frothy. Plenty of lacing and rings of foam left over as I quaff this beauty. Big roasted malt aroma mixed with malt sugar and molasses. Some hints of alcohol and chocolate and raisins. Tastes of molasses and sugar. Slight tickle of carbonation and alcohol. Some dried fruit. Nice viscous mouthfeel. Some heat from carbonation and alcohol. A slight bitterness on the back like some old coffee. Very good beer.

Rating #4100.  Black color with a very quickly falling head.  Dark honey and nutty aroma.  Some chocolate, roast and coffee notes.  Strong, dark, slightly bitter honey flavor.  Very roasty and fairly astringent.  Hints of coffee and chocolate, but the honey takes center stage.  Love it.

Bottle.  Strange but good.  Pours black with a medium brown head.  Aroma of chestnuts/hazelnuts with hints of honey, chocolate and mustiness.  Nutty chocolate flavor with some honey, licorice, fruit and grassy hops.  Smooth, slightly sweet and peaty finish.

Almost black with a dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate, honey and peated. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. Smooth and oily. 090212

Bottle. Black with medium brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, little honey and a little peat. Flavour is roasted malts, little peat, chocolate, coffee, spices, dark fruits, hops, little honey, hops and a little bitter.
Bottle. Huge creamy head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, soapy, herbs, honey, cocoa, coffee and notes of peat.

Not sure how to rate this. Very complex and rich aroma - herbal, woody.  The flavor was herbal and woody as well with some peat.  I sort of liked it and sort of thought it tasted a little medicinal.  A for effort but this didnt work for me. Serving: Bottle

500th rate. From a bottle. Pours black with a very nice looking metallic tan head. Nice big aroma of coffee, chocolate, dried fruit and bubblegum. Roast malt is more up front in the taste, smokey, chocolate, makes way to the fruitiness and a bubblegum finish. Thick as is gets, very heavy on the palate, quite sweet, doesnt finish very well. The sorachi is quite prominent, a hop Im not a fan of, lets it down a bit for me but otherwise a big and well balanced beer

Bottle in honour of Benhs 500th rate. Peace be with you Ben. Shalom. Pours black with a wonderful bronze head. Bubblegum on the nose. Sweet alcohol and roasted malt flavours. Warming. Syrupy, oily mouthfeel. Good gear like...

(Bottle, 0.5 l - BBE 25.11.16, at Hilpeä Hauki, 20120131) The beer poured black. Its head was medium sized and light brown. Aroma had roasted malts, chocolate, smoke, sweetness and molasses. Palate was medium bodied, warming and oily with medium carbonation. Flavours were roasted malts, chocolate, ash, sweetness, caramell, coffee and bitterness. Aftertaste was roasty, sweet and bitter. Rich and balanced taste but a bit harsh, too. Aging would quite likely improve this beer but its already a good and delicious one.

Bottle: Sweet malty, rich aroma. Notes of roasted malt, oak barrels, smoke, dried fruits, plums, coffe and chocolate. Black color, creamy brown (espresso like) head. Flavor is sweet and malty, roasty, fruity. Notes of honey, dark fruits, dark chocolate. Dry, roasty finish.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2012 Bottle from Utobeer. Colour is impressive, dark brown with red burgundy wine edges and a creamy tan head which dissapates quickly. Nose is very earthy, clay, waxy, then underneath that its nutty, red wine, chocolate, honey. Frankly a weird combination of flavours. Taste is damn good. Sweet earthy chocolate, hot choc cocoa powder, red wine, bit of light milky coffee. On the finish theres a bit of liquorice, roasted grain and peat with an alcohol bite. Surely this is an imperial stout?

0.5 l bottle bought from GBBF 2011.Black color. Rich aroma of hazelnuts and leather cream (shoe wax). Rich smoothly roasty flavor with coffee, honey, coconut, licorice and hazelnuts. Full soft body. A peculiar shoe wax aroma and flavor, not bad by any means, very good in fact.

Bottle 500 ml
 Aroma:  Lovely aroma. Best of best mead notes, herbal, soft, and sunny with floral twist. Hint of lavender and various herbs. Splendid.10- 
 Appearance:  brownish-black with large dark tanned brownish crown. Nice presented lace.4+
 Palate / Taste:  oily, thick bodied. Heavy brew yet not cloying. I wonder how much mead in in here? Sweet with alcohol warmth. Floral top, some alcoholic dryness as you go. Sticky palate. This brew is something else! World class offering.

Bottle @ Gallows Bird. Pours black with a thick, mocha-colored head. Aroma is strongly malty, roasted, dark fruits, honey, prune. Taste is malty, caramel, roasted, honey, dark fruits, dark cherries. Palate is full and a bit sticky. Very pleasant sipper.

500 ml bottle at the Gallows Bird XV Real Ale Festival, Espoo, Finland.
Pitch black colour with small tan head.
Roasted malt, sweet chocolate, dark fruits and mild metal in aroma. 
Flavour is also roasted malt, quite a lot sweetness, mild bitterness and dark fruits. Quite similar to Imperial Stout. Rich and tasty.

(500ml bottle,  BB 12.14, bottled 2010)  Pours a black body with a medium brown head.  Aroma of peat, nuts, banana bread, honey, mustiness, raisins, nuts, and basement.  Flavor of liquorice, peat, honey, chocolate, coffee, nuts, and banana.

500ml bottle. (Rating #500)
Pours pitch black, with a brown head.
Very complex aromas, roasted malt, licorice, spices, hops, coffee, chocolate, tar, dried fruits, plums, ashes, smoke.
Sweet, full bodied (and beyond), high bitterness, creamy CO2.
Extremely rich and complex, loads of fruit and roasted malts, coffee, tobacco, plums, chocolate, tar, smoke, hops. Let this one lie down for a few years. A beauty.
(2012-01-13)
Off tap at Sheffield tap. Massive sherry, dark fruits, port, red wine, honey. Very tasty.
Absolutely delicous, but can too easily become overpowering if consumed too quickly or at a quantity more than about half a bottle. Unique in taste, texture and aroma.

Sunday afternoon brew.  Pours dark brown with thin head.  Great nose of coffee and dark fruits. Tastes of smoke, chocolate, licorice, root beer, coffee, earth, and warming on finish.  Delightful beer for the season
Dark brown with a small, tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, some spices, vanilla, and nuts. Taste of the same, with odd spicing, and more vanilla.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with clingy tan haze.  Nose is like some sort of herbal cough syrup featuring root beer, rubber, spearmint and dank cellar.  Vaguely reminiscent of absinthe though this is actually drinkable.  Syrupy with a buzz.  Taste is licorice, peat, Mr. Pibb, burnt sugar and tree bark.  An odd one.
Beautiful rich dark colour with a thick creamy head. An almost overwhelming array of roasted, nutty flavours with a slightly underwhelming finish. A fine beer of its milieu.

Bottle with Colin. A black beer with a decent tan head. Beautiful meady, honey aroma with alcohol, roasty malt, coffee and caramel also. Flavours of honey and Christmas spices, cloves and cinnamon. Beautifully rich, oily mouth-feel. Moderate carbonation and light CO2 prickle. Alcohol is very well balanced. Lovely!

500mL rating #100 for this beer and celebrating my 3300th rating on this site! From Knightly Spirits in Orlando, FL. The pour is essentially ink, perhaps very deep sepia, with a large, reverse cascading mocha head. Good retention. Not a lot of lace. Nose is sweet red candies and sharp honey with hints of fresh citrus peel, licorice and peat (for once- the commercial description is pretty spot on). Taste is interesting: spicy, relatively oily, small flashes of cardboard, mild smoked meat, spicy espresso. Also some mild metallic character. No alcohol presence. My big qualm is the large presence of orange flavored Robitussin cough syrup and grape flavored Dimetapp medicine. Uh. Okay. Meaty savory palate. Nice lactic acid. Just way too much cough syrup character probably from the honey addition.
UPDATED: DEC 8, 2012 Aroma: smokey, rosted malts. Appearance: wood.Taste: Awesome mix of porter and a smoked. Palate: mb. Overall: 20/20

In short: A one-of-a-kind highly roasted, sweet and nutty dark ale that defies classification.  Good.
How: Bottle 500ml, consumed probably fresh two weeks after purchase.
The look: Very dark brown body topped by a medium tan head with medium retention
In long: Highly unusual nose that I would describe as burnt spicy wood with some cacao and a sweet pastry.  Taste is very roasted, burnt chocolate chips cookies, roasted nuts, crusty brownies, honey, peppery spiciness, burnt brown sugar, burnt tree bark, cocoa powder.  A little alcohol bite in the finish.  Aftertaste is roasted nuts, honey and cacao powder.  Overall the sweetness and high roastiness level were keeping each other in check and the beer remained quite drinkable for a 10% brew.  There was something very unusual about the entire thing that I dont think I was able to put into words, the beer was simply different.  Not a bad beer but a bit pricey for what it is, but you only live once, and you lived my life youd agree that once is already more than enough.
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 Una delle migliori bevute degli ultimi mesi. Straordinaria complessità olfattiva e gustativa.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2012 Bottled Winter 2010, opened Xmas 2011. Thick black pour, thick creamy espresso head that quickly dissipates after releasing a flourish of roasted chestnuts and honey. The flavours are nutty, sweet coffee, and chocolate, backed up with a subtle hop and honey backbone. The mouthfeel is thick and decadent, with the finish pleasantly warming.

Mine at last!  The aroma is very nice, honey, nuts, flowers, light chocolate, caramel.  The appearance is almost black, tan head.  From the appearance, it looks like a stout.  The flavor is chocolate, molasses, brown sugar, light coffee, nuts.  Very nice.  Medium/thick in body, creamy mouthfeel.  The finish is pine, honey sweetness, some booze warming.  Excellent.  Im a big sucker for the adventure of trying traditional ales, but this one was excellent in its own right.

Medbragt av Rune fra GBBF 11. Delt med ham og MrSoul under seanse i heimen 21 Sep 11. Svart. Høyt kremaktig skum. Mokkafarget. Skummet flater helt ut. Rik aroma: Lakris & sjokolade. Avrundet kompleks smak. Samme komponenter som i aromaen med med tilføyelse av lakris. Tørr kaffeavslutning. Alkoholen godt kamuflert. KI=4

Bottle. Label lists this as 9% ABV. Pours black with a tall, thick, frothy brown head. Aroma is rather strong grain notes, soft roast, honey, chocolate, burnt caramel and licorice. Touch of herbal notes as well. Taste is grains, roasted malt, licorice, burnt caramel, honey, herbal hops, chocolate covered nuts, light iodine, soft peat and light coffee. Body is thick and surprisingly creamy with a frothy, bubbly carbonation. Sticky sweetness in spots as well. Ends with more burnt caramel, honey notes, chocolate, coffee, herbal hops, and grains. Tasty and a nice surprise!
@ ACBF 2011. The aroma has chocolate malts and honey. Black coloured beer with a beige head. The taste is sweet, has heather honey, chocolate, coffee, some spice. Good body. Very nice!

500ml bottle from the Real Ale in a Bottle Bar, at GBBF 11. Shared back home with Finn and MrSoul. Lots of bubbles to a big, tan-coloured head with fine duration. Opaque black body. Distinctive aroma of roasted malts, dark spices and anise. Comprehensive taste profile containing earthy malts, almost like ash, dark honey and nuts added by notes of spices. Bittersweet endnotes of coffee. Integrated alcohol. Velvet mouth feel. Lovely (at Finns in Tromsø, 22.09.2011).

Bottle courtesy bu11zeye. Pours a very dark brown color with touches of tannish red near the light. Heavy body. Tan foamy head. Aroma is interesting! Dark chocolate notes, hazelnut, chocolate, perfume and fruit rind. Flavor is sweet chocolate, cappuccino, vanilla and sweet sugar. Dark malts and sweet chocolate. Very good!

50cl bottle.  Medium brown head that gradually dissipates, atop brown-black body.  Aroma is sweet, white chocolate, licorice, root beer, dark fruit, milk chocolate, vinous, some molasses.  Taste is sweet, raisin/plum, cocoa, some licorice/root beer, vinous, earthy, light white chocolate. Full body, low carbonation, somewhat sticky.

500 mL bottle into a pint glass at the Great British Beer Festival 2011.  Dark as night, oily head (though little of that).  Wonderful deep alcohol aroma.  Roasted and a little sweet, but also a bit earthy.  Very nice but pricey.  Good but a bit too alcoholy.  Nice but devastating!
Had this one at the ACBF 2011. Brown colored brew. Chesnut aroma, very strange, but ok. Chesnut in the flavor too, malts. Ok.

Bottle. Dark brown - almost black, short and fully diminishing head. Moderate to full, malty and sweet aroma, coffee and chocolate, fruitiness with dark fruits/berries. Body is medium to full, malty and sweetish flavor,some coffee and chocolate with roasted malt, fruitiness with some hoppyness. Finish is average to full, malty and sweetish, fruitiness and some roasted malt, some coffee and chocolate, some alcohol, faint hoppyness. Coffee/chocolate with fruitiness and light hoppyness do balance the sweetness of this strong ale - nice one.

Black pour with a mocha colored head.  Not much lace left behind.  Aroma was a bit odd.  Big time peppermint, or some odd lacquer, not too appeasing to be honest.  Flavors were similar, a good bit of sweetness mixed with a lacquer like booziness.  Some roast but overpowered by everything else.  Mouthfeel was slick, full, carbonation light.  Overall an odd brew, the 10% was mildly noticeable.  This one left me for a loop...

Medium dark brown head.  Opaque black body.  Deep roasty
chocolatey aroma with bitter oranges and earth notes.  Unusual.
Dry-sweet roasty alcoholic earthy taste with oranges and
chocolate notes. Full body. Soft, hot mouthfeel.  Dryish peppery
earthy chocolate aftertaste with bitter herbal orangey notes.
Unusual and interesting. Also quite drinkable for its strength.
(0.5l bottle. Cant remember where I bought it.)
Sampled @ ACBF 2011. Color black with small brown head. Aroma roasted, caramel, dark chocolate. Taste roasted, chocolate, fruits, hop.
50cl, new exclusive English brew Anno 2009, with honey, from Den Bierzolder Heule, very complex brew, sweet and spicy, yet not too heavy, balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!

[500ml bottle, The Bottle, York] Extremely black pour with a light brown coloured head. Aroma is very malty with coffee and liquorice notes. Very complex and warming on the palate  every sip gives a different experience. Bitter coffee, raisins, figs, alcohol burn, a medicinal tinge in there somewhere. Really very nice indeed, and would age beautifully [19042011] 500th rating!
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours black with a disappearting tan head and a sweet anise aroma. There is a fruity chestnut and coffee flavor with a dry chocolate finish. Strange and interesting.

Winter 2010 bottle from Charleston Beer Exchange. Pours black with a 3 finger creamy bubbly dark tan head. Aroma is quite fresh - almost suggests mint. Really quite clean and herby. Med plus body. Flavor is defintely dark fruits and anise, but theres all kinds of notes. Chocolate. The composite flavor is like nothing Ive experienced, and its disturbingly complex. In the finish a little orange seems to appear. Im overwhelmed.

17 April 2011, bottle. really black, nice foamy brown head that fades fast. nose is subtle for something this dark. something like a soft pepermine? maybe it is medicinal. heaby nutty aroma or maybe a nutty molasses. full body and faintly fizzy. really big beer! starting out there was a kind of medicinal/mouthwash. as it goes on more bitter coffee/astringent coffee comes out. keeps an astringency for a while. wow. i could happily drink this anytime!

Winter 2010 bottling (500ml, 10%, marked as best before of 12.14). Pours with a pitch black body and a large deep brown head. Great lace and some alcohol legs. Aromas of rich tobacco, honey, toffee, coffee, nuts, nutella, cereal, wheat, mocha, hersheys syrup, light smoke, a tinge of citrus. Bready and grainy. Very nice. Flavors of smoke, honey, cocoa, bitter, toffee, coffee, dusty cocoa, alcohol. Nice smokey, rich, deep malt complexity. Some sweetness. Dark fruits, cherries, hazelnuts. Bitter, earthy tobacco.

Hugely creamy mouthfeel, syrupy, mouth coating, boozy. Very good, but at $20 for a 500ml, I probably will not be buying it again any time soon.
Bottle from 2008, pours black with a tan head. Aroma of iodine. Flavour of roasted malts, iodine, slight espresso and a bitter finish. Seems a bit off, though quite nice.

Huge dark yellow-beige head, irregular, over virtually black beer. Rich cakey nose with toffee and speculoos, old books and a whiff of cypress, and hazelnut oil. Roasted chocolate cookies, again this oxydized-like cookies/old books flavour (hazelnut) and a spicy finish (cypress, rosemary,...) Perfumed, but not soapy, quite sweet but not cloying. Bitterish lining, spicy-soft roasted, but not really hoppy. Very rich, chewy MF, voluptuous, warming. Excellent rich, warming ale, it really grew upon me.  I wish I had some to open one every year!

Cask at Euston Tap, London last December. A black coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Aroma of dark fruit and roasted malt. Tastes roasty, malty, coffee, chocolate, spice, sweet, Christmasey and complex. Nice drop indeed.

Bottle at ACBF. Black, little bit of brown head. Liquorice and dark plumminess, touch of cinnamon and the tiniest bit of acetone. Flavour is molasses, espresso, cocoa, mixed spices (star anise?). Light mouthfeel, which is a little disappointing, but very drinkable.

05/03/2011 - 50cl bottle @ Alvinne Craft Beer Festival (2011-90) 
Black beer with a dark brown small head, unstable and non adhesive. Aroma: spices, alcohol, mocha, but mainly very strange spices and is it the honey? Taste: caramel, sweet dark sugar, mocha, spices, alcohol. Aftertaste: some carbon sour, mocha turning to coffee.

Bottle at ACBF 2011.
Black coloured with a small brown head.
Roasted aroma of caramel, liquorice and dark chocolate.
Fruity and light roasted flavour of dark chocolate and liquorice with notes of hops.
Sweet and roasted finish.

Bottle from Beer Ritz. Black pour with a tan head. Chocolate, raisin, dark fruit and coffee aroma. Very nice nose. Smoky flavours of dark chocolate and molasses, huge coffee burst. Sweet coffee-esque finish. Very, very nice indeed!
Dark brown beer. Somewhat strange smell and taste but hard to recognize, combined with some nuts. Very different beer but very good.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2011 Black with a darker brown head. Smell is sweet spiced cappuccino.  A bit weird but nice. Taste about the same, something very familiar, but cant place it. Good one. Special and a bit weird, but good.

I either have a bad batch of bottles or everyone has gone bonkers for liking this beer.  For the record I am drinking batch bottled Winter 2010.
It pours out beautifully, real dark ruby with dense creamy tan head.  The 1st sign of disaster is the nose, there is some classic caramel, oats & coffee but its overpowered by this weird gluey varnish character.  On tasting , the body is lovely & rounded, great conditioning, lovely rich nutty, chocolate & cocoa.  There is plenty of sweetness, but this is tempered nicely, but then the absolute disaster kicks in on the finish.  There is a really vile chemical varnish flavour going on where the honey has obvioulsy completely clashed, it says in the commercial description theres some peat on the finish, god knows where this peat would have come from, what would have been more honest is to say there is a vile glue flavour on the finish.  
This beer cost nearly £10 in a bottle & I had to throw it away. Just because everything else these guys brew is brilliant does not excuse this mess.

Bottle shared by kmweaver at Woodshop 5.0 (2/20/10): Pours an oily black with a large froth of light brown head. Has an herbal licorice and dark chocolate nose with some raisin and coffee notes. Starts with good body and fine carbonation with some earthy dark chocolate flavor and anise spice before a warming funky earthy coffee finish. A very unique and fairly complex brew.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, lending it a bit of acidity combined with something funky. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of roasted malt and soy sauce, and again somethin funky, leading to a dry roasted finish.
Thornbridge is maybe the best brewery from UK. This is a sort of  imperial stout, strong and dark and impressive at taste.

Cask at the Euston Tap. Pours opaque black with brown highlights and an out of control, beige head. Huge, sweet malt aroma with notes of chocolate, honey, hazelnuts and chestnuts. Flavor is extremely sweet, with lots of honey, caramelized demerara sugar, licorice, more nuts, light spices and earthy, lightly citric bitterness. Full in body with average carbonation and alcohol warmth. Finishes sweet with honey, chestnuts and chocolate, plus mild and lingering roasty bitterness. Wow. Simply amazing.

50cl bottle from the Doemens Euro Beer Star stash.   Thick black color with a medium-sized brown head.   Some alcohol and sticky burn aromas with some juniper, licorice, and honey.   Dark chocolate, licorioce, and honey are the main flavor components, with a moderate alcohol presence and a medium bitterness that lasts through the finish.   Full bodied with smooth carbonation.   Another nice dark ale from Thornbridge.

Cask at the Euston Tap, London on 5th November 2010. Impenetrably black with a pale brown frothy head. Roasted chestnut/hazelnut in a rich aroma, along with wood and earthy pungency. Nutty main kick with berry fruits/Christmas pudding and burnt sugar. Finish is slightly less intense, but contains lactic tastes, creaminess and a soapy note. Thick and fulfilling creamy mouthfeel. A treat.

Cask, Euston Tap.

Chocolate; coffee, cream on aroma. Amazing bitterness, proper espresso bitterness, chocolate, great drinkability, dangerously drinkable, feel this version is improved on the old batch, loads of oak,. smoke, definitely a hint of Margaux red wine which is just devine.
